entry.title: Forget Docker Compose: You Want Skaffold
entry.summary:
I still remember, back in 2015 when I was at Yelp, and I learned about Docker Compose. It was beautiful, like magic.

It kinda felt the same when I recently found out about Skaffold, a tool released by Google a year ago, and designed to make local Kubernetes development very easy!

It's kinda like a command line utility that allows for iterative local development against a Kubernetes cluster. Check this out:

  • It runs as a binary in your local machine (e.g. easily install with brew, etc.).
  • It uses yaml configuration to describe how your application should be built: you specify the Docker images for your service(s) and Skaffold will tag them and push them to any valid Docker image repository.
  • These images are ingested into your Kubernetes manifest and used to deploy changes to the clusters for every code change.
  • Skaffold watches your local development directory for filesystem changes and automatically builds and deploy your application to any local or remote Kubernetes cluster.
  • It is integrated to kubectl and GCP.
  • Skaffold not only works on your laptop as a dev tool, it also lets you reuse the same skaffold.yaml file to do deployments to your clusters in your continuous deployment system.

This is possible because different parts of Skaffold are exposed through different commands: * In resume, Skaffold makes development very easy: all you need to do is run skaffold dev (local development workflow on Minikube/Docker-for-Desktop) or skaffold run (continuous deployment environments like Jenkins, Travis CI etc.) to start the entire process creating Kubernetes pod(s) in a cluster with the Docker images of your application. In this single command, Skaffold can: 1. Build container images (either locally or remotely), 2. Push container images (unless the target is local cluster), 3. Update Kubernetes manifests with the correct image tags, 4. Deploy your application with kubectl apply, 5. Stream logs from the deployed/running Pods. 6 Watch for changes in the source code or Kubernetes manifests, and repeat 1-5
